bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom [Emilie M.] Reed, June 17, 1941

div1.p: Hench thanks Reed for lending her copy of her father's letters to him, and informs her of his plans for returning them to her. He also expresses the hope that she will have the letters published.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom [Emilie M.] Reed, June 17, 1941
div1.opener:
To Mrs. Blossom Reed
June 17, 1941
My dear Mrs. Reed:
div1.p:
It was so very nice to receive your kind note, again expressing
your interest in my Cleveland talk. I can assure you that my tribute was
a very sincere one.

I cannot tell you how much I appreciate your lending me the copy
of your father's letters. Since seeing you in Cleveland I have had to make
two more trips out of town so that I have been home very briefly. I will
get at your father letters immediately and will plan to make copies of such
portions as seem of special interest to me. We ought to be able to return
them to you in a day or so, and since this is apparently your only copy,
I will mail it by insured express.

I sincerely yope you can have these letters published somewhere,
I suspect that your own modesty interfered with the reception that this manu-
script received from the editors. In other words, I suspect that prospective
editors would have liked to have much more of your own writing and inter-
pretation of your father and his character rather than merely the collection
of letters.

It was indeed a great pleasure to meet you and I have told my
friends and my wife what a nice time we had.

I appreciate so much your mother's letter, and I am writing her
separately.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
Mrs. Blossom Reed
Blue Ridge Summits
Pennsylvania
